revised_title: Two-dimensional Aperture Synthesis in Lunar Radar Astronomy: Advancements and Applications
tldr: This article presents a method for two-dimensional aperture synthesis in lunar radar astronomy, allowing researchers to construct an unambiguous map of the lunar radar brightness distribution with an angular resolution of 3'. The technique involves measuring the complex amplitudes of returned signals and using Fourier transforms to recover the sky brightness distribution. The method has broader applications in studying distant objects and celestial bodies.
